|map_caption = Map of NASA Langley Research Center }} 'Langley Research Center'
('LaRC') is the oldest of NASA's field centers, located in Hampton, Virginia,
United States. It directly borders Poquoson, Virginia and Langley Air Force
Base. LaRC focuses primarily on aeronautical research, though the Apollo lunar
lander was flight-tested at the facility and a number of high-profile space
missions have been planned and designed on-site.

Established in 1917 by the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, the
Center currently devotes two-thirds of its programs to aeronautics, and the rest
to space. LaRC researchers use more than 40 wind tunnels to study improved
aircraft and spacecraft safety, performance, and efficiency. Between 1958 and
1963, when NASA started Project Mercury, LaRC served as the main office of the
Space Task Group, with the office being transferred to the Manned Spacecraft
Center (now the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center) in Houston in 1962–63.

The current director is Lesa B. Roe.
